I used the [SimpleAvroMessageDecoder](https://github.com/apache/pinot/blob/9275a430049ff0d2888cb353fc7ef369d53a171c/pinot-plugins/pinot-input-format/pinot-avro/src/main/java/org/apache/pinot/plugin/inputformat/avro/SimpleAvroMessageDecoder.java), the [JSONMessageDecoder](https://github.com/apache/pinot/blob/7e9ca6a5a4afe0d4e283ac1307c45430e474cbf2/pinot-plugins/pinot-input-format/pinot-json/src/main/java/org/apache/pinot/plugin/inputformat/json/JSONMessageDecoder.java), and the [ThriftDeserialization](https://github.com/apache/druid/blob/df4894afff5efb31264e98f39f4f14dd934ecc3d/extensions-contrib/thrift-extensions/src/main/java/org/apache/druid/data/input/thrift/ThriftDeserialization.java#L106) code from Apache Druid as a basis for getting this first pass together. I am working on some tests, but it may be a few weeks until I get back to this PR, so if anyone has some time between now and then to give me some notes or to get this over the finish line, then please do so. ## Upgrade Notes Does this PR prevent a zero down-time upgrade? (Assume upgrade order: Controller, Broker, Server, Minion) * [ ] Yes (Please label as **backward-incompat**, and complete the section below on Release Notes) Does this PR fix a zero-downtime upgrade introduced earlier? * [ ] Yes (Please label this as **backward-incompat**, and complete the section below on Release Notes) Does this PR otherwise need attention when creating release notes? Things to consider: * [x] Yes (Please label this PR as **release-notes** and complete the section on Release Notes) ## Release Notes There is a new props configuration named `stream.kafka.decoder.prop.thrift.class`. One way in which you can include this class is by placing it in the `CLASSPATH` by adding it to the [plugins folder](https://github.com/apache/pinot/blob/0500c121a115b4412b7a5b08452359e76d93b095/pinot-tools/src/main/resources/appAssemblerScriptTemplate#L110-L141). In the default case, this will be at :`/opt/pinot/plugins`. ## Documentation I have not adding this to the documentation yet. I will do it on my next pass.

title: Use maxEndTimeMs for merge/roll-up delay metrics.
body:
- For single level merge or the lowest merge level of multi-level, the equation is updated as 
```(Math.min(System.currentTimeMillis() - bufferTimeMs, maxEndTimeMs) - watermarkMs) / bucketTimeMs```
- For multi-level merge, the equation is 
```(Math.min(System.currentTimeMillis() - bufferTimeMs, lowerLevelWatermarkMs) - watermarkMs) / bucketTimeMs```

title: Update watermark if no segments present for a window. Fixes #6988
body:
This is happening because there are no segments to process for a particular time window.

`RealtimeToOfflineSegmentsTaskGenerator` gathers segments to process and `RealtimeToOfflineSegmentsTaskExecutor` updates the watermark in the post-processing step. For the scenario causing this bug, the watermark is never updated because no task is generated for execution.

This PR updates the watermark if there are no segments to process for a particular time window.

Fixes: https://github.com/apache/pinot/issues/6988

title: Round Robin IP addresses when retry uploading/downloading segments
body: ## Description When minion/server upload/download segments to/from deep store, the deep store may be backed by multiple hosts, while minion/server may always try to upload/download from the same host because: 1) DNS may not RR the IP addresses 2) OS cache the DNS result. This RB: * Round Robin IP addresses when retry upload/downloading segments * Make 404 a temporary exception, as the deep store may be backed by multiple hosts, if singe host is down, can retry with another host. cc @jackjlli ## Upgrade Notes Does this PR prevent a zero down-time upgrade? (Assume upgrade order: Controller, Broker, Server, Minion) * [ ] Yes (Please label as **backward-incompat**, and complete the section below on Release Notes) Does this PR fix a zero-downtime upgrade introduced earlier? * [ ] Yes (Please label this as **backward-incompat**, and complete the section below on Release Notes) Does this PR otherwise need attention when creating release notes? Things to consider: - New configuration options - Deprecation of configurations - Signature changes to public methods/interfaces - New plugins added or old plugins removed * [ ] Yes (Please label this PR as **release-notes** and complete the section on Release Notes) ## Release Notes ## Documentation

title: Adding new generic method in ClusterInfoAccessor for getting ZNRecord
body: ## Description Adding new generic method in ClusterInfoAccessor for getting a minion task metadata ZNRecord. Deleted the existing ZNRecord methods (`getMinionRealtimeToOfflineSegmentsTaskMetadata` and `getMinionMergeRollupTaskZNRecord`) that do the same thing and migrated them to use the new generic method. This new method just wraps the `MinionTaskMetadataUtils.fetchTaskMetadata` static method so there isn't much to test. Existing unit tests for the task generators should provide enough coverage. ## Upgrade Notes Does this PR prevent a zero down-time upgrade? title: Enhance TableRebalancer to offload the segments from most loaded instances first
body:
When TableRebalancer rebalances a table without downtime, it goes over multiple steps to reach the target assignment. In order to keep the available replicas, the algorithm picks the first instance in alphabetical order to move the segment. This can cause the instances with smaller name to be overloaded during the intermediate assignments.
This PR enhances the algorithm to track the number of segments to be offloaded for each instance between the current assignment and the target assignment, and always offload the segment from the instances with most segments to be offloaded. With the enhancement, it is guaranteed that during the rebalance, no segment will be moved to the instances to be offloaded.

title: EXPLAIN PLAN
body: ## Description This PR is for adding support for EXPLAIN PLAN functionality in Pinot. EXPLAIN PLAN query results show the physical plan that Pinot will use to evaluate the query embedded within the EXPLAIN PLAN statement. ``` Query: EXPLAIN PLAN FOR SELECT playerID, playerName FROM baseballStats LIMIT 10 Results: BROKER_REDUCE(limit:10) | 0 | -1| COMBINE_SELECT | 1 | 0 | SELECT(selectList:playerID, playerName) | 2 | 1 | TRANSFORM_PASSTHROUGH(transformFuncs:) | 3 | 2 | PROJECT(playerName, playerID) | 4 | 3 | FILTER_MATCH_ENTIRE_SEGMENT(docs:97889) | 5 | 4 | ``` First column represents the physical operator that Pinot executes as part of this query's execution plan. The second column is the id of the operator (`BROKER_REDUCE` has an id of 0; while as, `SELECT` has an id of 2). The third column is id of the parent operator (`BROKER_REDUCE` has parent id -1, i.e does not have a parent; while as, `TRANSFORM_PASSTHROUGH` has parent id of 2 which is the SELECT` operator). Combined together the id column and the parent_id column can be used to rebuild a representation of the physical operator tree that Pinot would have used to execute the query. Design document (created by @SabrinaZhaozyf in collaboration with @siddharthteotia) is available [here](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1lBMGcR65JY_8iIUCA1iCazzn0LzTVxMJlPzFIsZ7TRk/edit#heading=h.7hobd7rxyfam). Issue #6978. An initial implementation of the EXPLAIN PLAN functionality by @SabrinaZhaozyf (Phase 1 in the design document) is [here](https://github.com/apache/pinot/pull/7210). This PR is derived from a Phase-2 prototype created by @SabrinaZhaozyf. For overall design please refer to the design document linked above. For examples, see `ExplainPlanQueriesTest` or better yet, download this PR as a [patch](https://patch-diff.githubusercontent.com/raw/apache/pinot/pull/7568.patch) and apply to your local pinot codebase, before running EXPLAIN PLAN queries in Quickstart console. Since this PR has been through a few iterations, in case of discrepancies with any existing documentation or code, this PR should be considered as the source of truth. The purpose of this PR is to implement basic EXPLAIN PLAN functionality that can evolve over time, but not to implement a final and complete version of EXPLAIN PLAN functionality. Further enhancement and evolution (such as including rewrite, costing, profiling information in EXPLAIN PLAN output as discussed in design document) will likely occur and lead to significant changes in the output of EXPLAIN PLAN queries. Hence, no backward compatibility guarantees should be assumed. The output of EXPLAIN PLAN queries is for information purposes only and is expected to change from version to version. **pinot-common module code changes** - _CalciteSqlParser.java_ Calcite's representation of EXPLAIN PLAN query is converted into a `PinotQuery`. Note that `PinotQuery` (which is derived from `query.thrift`) has a new `boolean` member `explain` which indicates whether a query is EXPLAIN PLAN query or a regular query. - _DataSchema.java_ Defines the schema for the result table of EXPLAIN PLAN query. This needs to be accessible from both the Server and Broker code. - _Other Changes_ Rest of the changes in this package are due to automated changes made my thrift compiler (removing blank spaces at the end of lines and updating date in autogenerated annotation) that are not relevant to this PR. **pinot-broker module code changes** - _BaseBrokerRequestHandler_ Send EXPLAIN PLAN query to a single server for constructing a response. If EXPLAIN is on a query that contains only literals in the SELECT list then Broker itself will create and return a response without contacting Server. - _LiteralOnlyBrokerRequestTest_ Test case for running EXPLAIN on a query that contains only literals in the SELECT list. - _org.apache.pinot.core.query.reduce.ExplainPlanDataTableReducer and ResultReduceFactory_ When the broker receives EXPLAIN PLAN query response from server, a `BROKER_REDUCE` entry is added as the parent of the current root entry in the EXPLAIN PLAN resultset. **pinot-core module code changes** - _ServerQueryRequest_ Added `boolean` member variable `_explain` to keep track of whether this `ServerQueryRequest` is for EXPLAIN PLAN query for a regular query. - _ServerQueryExecutorV1Impl_ If the query is marked as EXPLAIN PLAN query, then do a preorder traversal of the operator tree for creating a tabular output that will be used as result of the EXPLAIN PLAN query. - _ExplainPlanDataTableReducer and ResultReduceFactory_ Described above under the pinot-broker package. - _Other Changes_ Other changes in this package (see `Operator` interface and implementations, `pinot.core.plan` classes, and `pinot.core.query.aggregation.function` classes) were for ensuring that operator information can be accessed for creating an EXPLAIN PLAN result set. In particular the following functions were added to the Operator interface: ``` /** @return Name of this operator */ String getOperatorName(); /** @return List of {@link Operator}s that this operator depends upon. */ List getChildOperators(); /** @return Explain plan name of this operator */ String getExplainPlanName(); /** @return Description of this operator for Explain Plan */ String toExplainString(); ``` and Function classes (`pinot.core.query.aggregation.function classes`) where modified to include `toExplainString()` method for generating EXPLAIN PLAN output. **pinot-spi package code changes** - _CommonConstants.java_ Declared a constant that is used in `ServerQueryRequest` constructor used by `GrpcQueryServer`. **Testing** _ExplainPlanQueriesTest_ contain test cases for verifying EXPLAIN PLAN functionality. ## Upgrade Notes Does this PR prevent a zero down-time upgrade? (Assume upgrade order: Controller, Broker, Server, Minion) * [ ] Yes (Please label as **backward-incompat**, and complete the section below on Release Notes) Does this PR fix a zero-downtime upgrade introduced earlier? * [ ] Yes (Please label this as **backward-incompat**, and complete the section below on Release Notes) Does this PR otherwise need attention when creating release notes? Things to consider: - New configuration options - Deprecation of configurations - Signature changes to public methods/interfaces - New plugins added or old plugins removed * [ ] Yes (Please label this PR as **release-notes** and complete the section on Release Notes) ## Release Notes ## Documentation

title: TableConfigBuilder init from TableConfig
body:
## Description
This allows TableConfigBuilder init from TableConfig.

## Goal
Goal of this PR is having an easy way to clone a tableConfig, modify some subfields and construct a new one tableConfig. 
Currently there's no easy way to do so. 

## Alternative solutions
solution 1 is to go with the TableConfigBuilder path (this PR)
- Pro: it explicitly ask the user to copy the tableConfig because it doesn't expose setter directly.
- Con: there's deep-copy overhead; there's maintenance cost in TableConfigBuilder when adding/changing configs


solution 2 is to directly add field setter to TableConfig
- Pro: easy and straightforward
- Con: doesn't prevent accident change to tableConfig without a copy;

Since config change usually doesn't affect performance-critical path I prefer solution1 because of its auto safety against accidental config changes. but open to solution2 or other suggestions.

title: allow queries to missing columns to fill in default value
body: ## Description Segments are pruned when any of the columns are missing from the schema for the segment, so when querying, no records are returned This has a drawback which means that default values need to be backfilled when there are schema changes, but it also prevents use cases like querying entity-attribute-value columns by attribute. With this change, segments are only pruned if none of the columns are known in the schema for that segment (and this lenience could be configurable and off by default), and when the column is unknown at the segment level, a `MissingColumnDataSource` is created, which results in default values being populated in the query output. The `ForwardIndexReader` is intended to be overridden so that plugins can change missing column resolution, to e.g. filter a special EAV column by the name of the attribute missing in the schema. This works, but has some drawbacks, notably that the column's type is hardcoded to string. This draft PR is here for feedback about the approach. ## Upgrade Notes Does this PR prevent a zero down-time upgrade? title: fix `SegmentGenerationWithTimeColumnTest`
body: ## Description Fix #7534. This test would fail when timestamps were generated in the first or last day and the simple date mode was used. There isn't enough information to get a number of milliseconds in UTC. We don't know which timezone the simple date is in, but also don't know that there _isn't_ a timezone in the format string either, so the second change ensures that we don't test within a day of the minimum or maximum allowed number of milliseconds. This has no functional impact, it only relates to interval validation and Pinot wasn't live in 1971, I don't want to make a prediction about 2071. I added a couple of tests to fix the seed for degenerate cases. ## Upgrade Notes Does this PR prevent a zero down-time upgrade? title: map bitmaps through a bounded window to avoid excessive disk pressure…
body: ## Description Having discussed the problem with @suddendust and @subintp, the memory mapping error observed in #7476 appears to be correlated with very high disk usage, rather than high tmpfs usage as I initially suspected. They are using inverted and range indexes. The assumption behind `BitmapInvertedIndexWriter` is that there is a lot of disk space available, and that it's ok to overmap and truncate in order to avoid syscall overhead, but this results in high disk usage. Allocating file space for the serialised inverted indexes as it is needed feels like a good usability tradeoff. The strategy builds on some knowledge about how the bitmaps get serialised: a single bitmap never needs more than 256MB, so we never map more than 256MB at a time. Bitmaps should be fairly sparse most of the time, so we guess that we need `numBitmaps * 128KB` but if this estimate proves to be too small, the pessimistic 256MB is used for the next section. An alternative approach I considered is to just build the bitmaps all at once on heap, compute their sizes, then map the space needed once, which would be optimal in terms of disk usage and syscalls, but may lead to a little extra medium lifespan garbage. ## Upgrade Notes Does this PR prevent a zero down-time upgrade? title: In TableRebalancer, allow increasing from 1 replica without downtime
body: Currently when rebalancing a table without downtime, the min available replicas check is performed on the min replica of current and target assignment. (_bitmapQuantile) (_distribution) (_numDocs) (_seed) (_thresholdQuantile) Mode Cnt Score Error Units BenchmarkScanDocIdIterators.benchmarkSVLong 1 UNIFORM(0,10000000) 10000000 42 1 avgt 5 19.856 ± 0.839 ms/op BenchmarkScanDocIdIterators.benchmarkSVLong 1 UNIFORM(0,10000000) 10000000 42 2 avgt 5 20.061 ± 1.085 ms/op BenchmarkScanDocIdIterators.benchmarkSVLong 2 UNIFORM(0,10000000) 10000000 42 1 avgt 5 41.006 ± 1.170 ms/op BenchmarkScanDocIdIterators.benchmarkSVLong 2 UNIFORM(0,10000000) 10000000 42 2 avgt 5 34.342 ± 0.271 ms/o ``` At 8a0116404b54c528131dfc6b1be6157d48317982 (the improvement) we have: ``` Benchmark (_bitmapQuantile) (_distribution) (_numDocs) (_seed) (_thresholdQuantile) Mode Cnt Score Error Units BenchmarkScanDocIdIterators.benchmarkSVLong 1 UNIFORM(0,10000000) 10000000 42 1 avgt 5 15.022 ± 1.026 ms/op BenchmarkScanDocIdIterators.benchmarkSVLong 1 UNIFORM(0,10000000) 10000000 42 2 avgt 5 14.576 ± 1.762 ms/op BenchmarkScanDocIdIterators.benchmarkSVLong 2 UNIFORM(0,10000000) 10000000 42 1 avgt 5 35.679 ± 1.913 ms/op BenchmarkScanDocIdIterators.benchmarkSVLong 2 UNIFORM(0,10000000) 10000000 42 2 avgt 5 25.985 ± 0.547 ms/op ``` At 11871a0ccc38f4a7e52d8af5147c1126c8a4b191 (better result size prediction) we have: ``` Benchmark (_bitmapQuantile) (_distribution) (_numDocs) (_seed) (_thresholdQuantile) Mode Cnt Score Error Units BenchmarkScanDocIdIterators.benchmarkSVLong 1 UNIFORM(0,10000000) 10000000 42 1 avgt 5 14.498 ± 0.856 ms/op BenchmarkScanDocIdIterators.benchmarkSVLong 1 UNIFORM(0,10000000) 10000000 42 2 avgt 5 14.548 ± 0.930 ms/op BenchmarkScanDocIdIterators.benchmarkSVLong 2 UNIFORM(0,10000000) 10000000 42 1 avgt 5 33.848 ± 0.543 ms/op BenchmarkScanDocIdIterators.benchmarkSVLong 2 UNIFORM(0,10000000) 10000000 42 2 avgt 5 25.450 ± 0.264 ms/op ``` Note that there is an aspect of space time tradeoff here, in that we allocate a one kilobyte buffer per column scan, but this is negligible compared to title: Enhance TableCache to support schema name different from table name
body:
## Description
Enhance the TableCache to support the case where table schema name is not the same as the raw table name.
We recommend configuring the schema name the same as the raw table name, but it is not enforced. This PR fixes the issue of not able to find the schema from TableCache when its name is not the same as the raw table name. Query optimizers rely on the schema from the TableCache to optimize the query.

title: add validation for realtimeToOffline task
body:
Based on 
https://docs.pinot.apache.org/operators/operating-pinot/pinot-managed-offline-flows

Currently the task configs are not parsed until task generation, which should be validated sooner. Adding a validation for realtimeToOffline task

However a more general solution should be:
1. add validateConfig method to PinotTaskGenerator
2. make validateTaskConfigs reflectively call validateConfig provided by the concrete impl of PinotTaskGenerator  

This way we don't really need to duplicate config checkers between PinotTaskGenerator impl and within TableConfigUtils. (such as the task name copy and all other config parsing logic)

title: Support JSON queries with top-level array path expression.
body: ## Description This PR allows for supporting top-level array path expressions (`jsonColumn[1]` in the query below) in JSON queries. `SELECT jsonColumn[1] FROM testTable WHERE intColumn=14` **Note:** Ideally top-level path expressions should be specified as `jsonColumn.[1]`(dot between column name and array subscript). However, Calcite parser will throw error with this path expressions and hence as a workaround this PR is adding support for specifying top-level path expressions as `jsonColumn[1]` (without any dot). This latter path expression should be treated as a shortcut to the former path expression (and is not expected to cause any compatibility issues if and when we add support for full json path expressions in Calcite grammar). ## Upgrade Notes Does this PR prevent a zero down-time upgrade? title: Move acquire/release to right before/after execution call
body:
1) Add more info to FetchContext 
2) Make AcquireReleaseOperator take the plan instead of the operator for the child, to ensure acquire can happen before buffers accessed in planning
3) Move acquire release to BaseCombineOperator level, to better ensure release only happens after buffer access are done

To ensure clean acquire/release semantics, dataBuffers can no longer cache DirectByteBuffers. Removing it from BitmapInvertedIndexReader, RangeInvertedIndexReader and NullValueVectorReaderImpl.
Included jmh benchmarks in the change, which shows
1. while cached bitmaps outperform in a setup with large heap and high repeatability, it performs significantly worse in a setup with tight heap and low repeatability, compared to always building the bitmap.
2. in the case where alwaysBuild performed slower, the overhead we're talking about here is <1 microseconds per read. In the case where alwaysBuild performed better, it outdid by 4.6 microseconds per read.
3. These results remain consistent regardless of low/high cardinality
